author: David Welch
title: US truck sales help push General Motors to record earnings | Americas
text:
Related articles Toyota recalls 6.5-million cars over window switches that could ignite Fiat Chrysler falls as Ferrari misses investors’ high expectations Tata Steel chops jobs in UK amid industry crisis DETROIT — General Motors reported third-quarter profit that beat analysts’ estimates as strong light-truck sales in the US and stable operations in China produced a record $3.1bn in adjusted earnings before interest and taxes (ebit).
The company said adjusted earnings per share were $1.50, beating the $1.19 average of 16 analyst estimates.
The company credited strong margins in North America and only a slight decline in China, where car sales have struggled. Ebit, excluding about $1.5bn in legal costs, mostly related to the small-car ignition-switch recall, totalled $3.1bn.
GM’s profit rebounded from a year earlier as US buyers continue their love affair with trucks and the nation’s largest car maker overcame a tough car market in China by boosting sales of more expensive sport utility vehicles.
North American earnings before interest and taxes were a record $3.3bn.
"These results reflect on our work to capitalise on our strengths in the US and China," CEO Mary Barra said in a statement. "GM is a vastly different company today than it was five years ago."
The company’s equity income from the China joint venture slipped to $467m. Vehicle sales have struggled in the market, with GM’s sales falling 4.2% in the quarter. GM is keeping profit afloat with crossovers like the Chevrolet Trax and Buick Envision, representing more than 17% of sales by GM and its joint ventures in September, up from 6% a year ago.
In the quarter, GM took a charge of $1.5bn related to its ignition switch recall, with $900m going to a settlement with the US Department of Justice and the rest to settle lawsuits related to death and injury cases.
In Europe and South America, where GM has struggled to make a profit, the company continues to lose money. The European business cut its losses nearly in half from a year ago to $231m, while GM lost $217m in South America. In the same quarter last year, GM lost $32m in South America.
